title: Fourth Post
text:
‚úçÔ∏è Introduction
Welcome! This post is a demonstration of how a typical Quarto blog post might look.
It includes headings, inline formatting, R code, a data visualisation, tables, and more.
Quarto allows you to write in markdown, embed live code, and include beautiful, reproducible outputs ‚Äî all in one place.
Whether you‚Äôre documenting your research, writing tutorials, or just keeping notes, it gives you the flexibility of code and prose combined.

title: Fourth Post
text:
üìã Lists

Unordered list

Quarto supports markdown out of the box

Code can be executed and rendered inline

You can embed LaTeX, HTML, or call external files



Ordered list

Install R and RStudio

Install Quarto CLI

Start writing posts like this one

title: Fourth Post
text:
üí¨ A Quote for Good Measure

‚ÄúA picture is worth a thousand words. A good plot is worth even more in R.‚Äù
‚Äî You, after adopting Quarto

title: Fourth Post
text:
üìä R Code and Visualisation
Let‚Äôs explore a classic dataset in R: mtcars. Below is a simple scatter plot showing how miles per gallon (mpg) relates to car weight (wt).

library(ggplot2)

mtcars |>
ggplot(aes(x = wt, y = mpg)) +
  geom_point(color = "#0072B2", size = 3) +
  labs(
    title = "MPG vs Weight",
    x = "Weight (1000 lbs)",
    y = "Miles per Gallon",
    caption = "Figure 1. Scatterplot of fuel efficiency vs car weight using the mtcars dataset."
  ) +
  theme_minimal()
